name: strontium mine operation and beneficiation | strontium sulfate, 90% SrSO4 | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24751/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg strontium sulfate (SrSO4, 90% concentrate) from celestite ores. Celestite is the mineral available at the mining site and includes strontium sulfate (i.e. the marketable product) and impurities, which are eliminated through the beneficiation process. Concentrated strontium sulfate is an intermediate product: it is indeed used as a precursor for the production of strontium carbonate. The system includes consumption of raw materials, energy, infrastructure, as well as the generation of emissions to air and water. Production during stable operation conditions is represented. The source of the data (Nuss & Eckelman, 2014) has been applied to Spain, which represents 41% of global celestite production in 2019 (USGS 2020). ;References:;;Nuss, P., & Eckelman, M. J. (2014). Life cycle assessment of metals: a scientific synthesis. PLoS One, 9(7), e101298. ;USGS 2020. Mineral Commodity Summaries - Strontium. Available at: https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2020/mcs2020.pdf;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

The activity starts with the construction of the mine site and the extraction of celestite ore (SrSO4)

The activity ends with the production of strontium sulfate 90% concentrate. The majority of strontium (metal, carbonate, etc.) producers require at least 90% strontium sulfate content for economic profitability.

Reference: 
USGS, 2015 - Minerals Yearbook, Strontium. Available at: https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/prd-wret/assets/palladium/production/mineral-pubs/strontium/myb1-2015-stron.pdf
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered valid from 2014 (year of the publication) to 2020.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is considered representative of Spanish extraction of strontium sulfate from celestite ores.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Celestite ores (SrSO4) are mined from both open cast and underground mines. Due to a lack of knowledge on the exact global share of both operations, the open-cast mining is assumed in this dataset. About 47 to 87 kg of celestite (3.8-3.9 g/cm3) are contained in one cubic meter of ore containing limestone, quartz, gypsum, and dolomite (all <3 g/cm3). During the mine operations, celestite is broken by drilling and blasting and the raw ore is mined. Assuming an average yield of 67 kg celestite/m3 ore, an average  density of 3.85 t/m3 ore, and a recovery efficiency of 75%, 76.62 kg of ore are mined per kg of celestite. Impurities are removed via desliming and celestite separated from other ores by means of density separation. Between 80% and 95% of strontium sulfate contained in the ore can be extracted.;References:; ;Nuss, P., & Eckelman, M. J. (2014). Life cycle assessment of metals: a scientific synthesis. PLoS One, 9(7), e101298.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Some input values are extrapolated from other Ecoinvent datasets (see comments in Exchanges)

flow.name: strontium sulfate, 90% SrSO4
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

exchanges.description: Literature. Water used for desliming process. The same value per kg ore as in barite mining was taken (12600 l water/m3 ore --> 12.6 m3 water/m3 ore * 1/(67 kg/m3 ore) / 0.75 = 0.25 m3/kg)

Calculated value. Data used in the calculation are taken from the ecoinvent dataset producing "mine infrastructure, open cast, non-ferrous metal" considering Lifetime 50a; output: 400'000 t ore per year.  

The Spanish national production volume of SrSO4 is 90000 t/year in 2018 (USGS 2020) and two mining sites in Spain cover most of the SrSO4 production at national level. Specifically, they are the mine site in Escuzar/Granada with 31 years lifetime (ref.: https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/prd-wret/assets/palladium/production/mineral-pubs/strontium/stronmyb03.pdf) the mine in Montevive/Granada with 60 years lifetime (ref.: https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/prd-wret/assets/palladium/production/mineral-pubs/strontium/stronmyb03.pdf).

EcoSpold01Location=RER
Based on data for manganese mining. An average of 0.26 kg of explosives per tonne of mined ore is needed (Classen et al. 2009).

Reference:
Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S., Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle Inventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, Online-Version under: www.ecoinvent.ch

exchanges.description:
Calculated, based on strontium content of celestite, recovery efficiency of 75% and 90% concentration of final product (Nuss & Eckelmna, 2014). Sr MW = 87.62; celestite (SrSO4) MW = 183.68 

--> % SrSO4 concentrate in final product * (MW Sr/MW SrSO4)/ recovery_rate
Literature. Estimated, based on 0.07 MJ electricity per kg ore from barite mining, 76.62 kg celestite ore mined and conversion factor of 0.2778 kWh/MJ.

exchanges.description:
Literature. The original amount applied to the datasets "copper mine operation and beneficiation, sulfide ore" is reported in Classen et al. (2009): conveyor belts are assumed wit a capacity of 2000 t/h which yields 7.6E-5 m conveyor belt required per tonne mined raw ore. 

Reference: 
Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S., Doka G., Jungbluth N. and Tuchschmid M. (2009) Life Cycle Inventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1 No.10. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
